loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong is a 61-year-old married woman with six children. She is very hard working in her fishing business. She requested a loan to buy a new engine for her fishing boat. She has been in this business for 35 years. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy a new engine for her fishing boat

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Mrs. Van, 27 years old, is a hardworking woman. She is living in a village with her family. She is married. She is busy with agriculture and has a practice in this sphere. 

After getting married, she and her husband started to keep livestock to earn money to live. She wants to enlarge her business and buy more livestock so she asked for a loan to buy livestock.

loans.use: To enlarge her business and buy more livestock

loans.name: Meo

texts.en: Mrs. Meo, 52 years old, is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with four children. She runs a fishing business and requested a loan through QB WDF in order to buy fishing nets and other equipment. She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like her general store. She dreams that one day, she will be able to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and other equipment to expand her business activities

loans.name: Lien

texts.en:
This is Lien, 36 years of age, who earns a living by means of fishing. In addition to that, she is also engaged in a hog-raising business. She raises and sells hogs. She is asking for a loan to purchase fuel for the motorboat and pig feed. These will help boost her fishing livelihood and also improve the way she raises hogs. 

Thus, in few months to come, she will be raising quality hogs and start to augment her income. She can then start to pay her obligations and be able to balance her earnings. She hopes that she can be successful in handling both her businesses for sustainable living.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for the motorboat and pig feed

loans.name: Diep

texts.en: Diep is 48 years old, married and has four children. Her youngest child is 19 years old. She goes fishing and sells fresh fish to the local people in her community. She needs funds to augment her catch. She is asking for a loan to purchase a fishing net. These are essentials in her day-to-day fishing activities. With the net, it will help improve her yield and variety of fish she catches. That will enable her to provide nutritious meals to the family and be able to continue to send her youngest child to college as well. In the future, she hopes to expand her business to make it productive and profitable.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net to expand her business

loans.name: Luong

texts.en:
Luong is 55 years old and married, and she has four children. She is a small-scale farmer and has been growing crops to sell for the last 30 years.

She will use the loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for use on her farm, to enable her to harvest more farm produce to sell and thus make more profits to support her family.

She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. Her future hopes are to improve her farming, make more income, and support her family.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer for use on her farm

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en:
Thuy is 31 years old. She lives with her husband and three children. She and her husband run their farm. While rearing animals and cultivating different type of crops, they sell the gathered harvest in local markets and earn income for the family's living.

In order to improve the living conditions of her family, Thuy plans to expand her business. This requires a lot of dedication and effort. Since the cattle breeding is profitable, she wants the business to continue and prosper. She asks for this loan to purchase two pigs and oxen to enlarge the farm and earn more income for her family's living.

loans.use: to purchase two pigs and oxen to enlarge the farm and earn more income for her family's living

loans.name: Loi

texts.en: Loi is 59 years old, married, and has three children. She operates a fishing business and owns fish cages. She earns a meager income each month doing this type of work to support the needs of her family, especially her children's education. Loi requested a loan to repair and overhaul her fishing boat and maintain other fishing equipment to improve and expand her fishing business. In the future, she hopes to concrete her house.

loans.use: To repair and overhaul her fishing boat and maintain other fishing equipment to improve and expand her fishing business

loans.name: Hoai

texts.en: Mrs. Hoai is a 61-year-old mother of two children. She makes a living working one hour a day raising livestock, a business she inherited from her family and which has allowed her to forge ahead with her family. One of the reasons this woman struggles day after day is to fulfill her dream of paying for the education of her children, since she worries a lot about their well-being. She is requesting a loan to buy feed wholesale and renovate the place where she keeps her livestock.

loans.use: to buy feed wholesale and renovate the place where she keeps her livestock.

loans.name: Thao

texts.en: Mrs. Thao is 34 years old, married and has two children. She has always earned her living from agriculture and raising livestock alongside her family who taught her these skills. For some months now she has had her own pigs to raise which she fattens and then sells in various parts of town. Her goal is to increase the number of pigs she is raising. She is seeking a loan to buy several pigs and the feed she requires to raise them. The money she earns from expanding her business will increase and she will be able to have a better standard of living with no financial problems. Her two children depend on the success of her business. Her greatest dream is to have a house of her own and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy several pigs and the feed to expand her business.

loans.name: Hue

texts.en:
Hue is 46 years old and sells chickens and eggs in the rural town where she has been working tirelessly to help her husband improve their small business. She never takes a day off, but she still needs help so that she can take her business to the next level. 

She would like to use this loan to buy more hens and chickens for her inventory, to thereby increase her sales whilst also establishing a level of sustainability for the long term.

She and her husband are incredibly motivated to improve the lives of their two children. They dream of one day being able to provide them with a great education and a better home to live in, and with your help they can make this happen.

loans.use: to buy more hens and chickens for her inventory and ultimately to increase her sales

loans.name: Hoan

texts.en:
Hoan is a 32-year-old married mother of two children, both of whom are currently in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur with a fishing business.

She has requested a loan to purchase additional materials for her fishing business. 

Hoan has been in this business for 10 years now. She would like to build and expand her business so she can secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her fishing business

loans.name: Duyen

texts.en:
A mother of two schoolchildren, Mrs. Duyen  is 31 years old. To improve her family’s living conditions, she grows rice on a 1 hectare area of land. Moreover, she earns additional income via pig-raising. She has been involved with her business for a long time. 

She will spend her entire loan to buy more piglets and pig feed to support her pig-raising business. She hopes that she can gain additional income to update her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy more piglets and pig feed to support her pig-raising business

loans.name: Hao

texts.en:
Mrs. Hao is 54 years old, married and has two children. She is a poultry farmer and has been selling eggs and chickens to her customers. 

She will use the loan to buy poultry feeds such as chick mash and layer mash. She hopes this will enable her to get more eggs and chickens to sell and that she will generate more income to support her family. 

Her future hopes and dreams are to be a successful poultry farmer, educate her children and live a comfortable life with her family.

loans.use: to buy poultry feeds such as chick mash and layer mash to expand her business activities

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en: Mrs. Phuong  is 45 years old, married and has two children. She has daily income from pig raising activity and farm so she is able to repay the loan monthly as scheduled. The loan will be used to buy poultry feed, and will help Mrs. Phuong  generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her family. She hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy poultry feed to expand and increase income for her family

loans.name: Mother Teresha Shg-C Group

texts.en:
Pushpanjali is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the village of Christianpeta in Koraput District of Odisha state, India. She is the one standing on the left. 

Pushpanjali is a tailor by profession. She currently runs her business from her family’s front porch because she cannot afford to rent office space. Pushpanjali supports her family through her business. She is the only earning person in her family as she got married at very young stage and now her husband's age does not allow him to do any work. She has faced much trouble in her small life and now she wants to save some money for her children's education. 

Pushpanjali together with her group member Sunil Prativa is requesting a loan amount of 36,000 INR from Kiva through People's Forum. Pushpanjali will use her portion of the loan amount to rent space and purchase more sewing materials for her business. As a result of receiving the loan, she hopes to improve her family’s standard of living and send her children to school.

loans.use: to rent a space for her tailoring business and buy more sewing materials.

loans.name: Mother Teresha Shg-B Group

texts.en:
Mother Teresha SHG-B was formed by gathering like-minded women, from similar socio-economic status, residing in a small village of the Koraput district of Odisha. 

Pratiti, standing on the left is the featured borrower of this group. Pratiti has a small scale business and is very hardworking. But in spite of her effort she can hardly manage her basic needs like food, clothes, etc. from her family income and is left with no savings for her children's education. 

With the intention to increase her savings, Pratiti along with her group member Magadalini approached Peoples Forum for a group loan of 36,000 INR. From this loan, Pratiti will add more varieties of fresh and dry fish and will expand her fish shop and Magadalini will be able to add more stock to her grocery shop. 

Pratiti will be using her savings which she would make after expansion of her business to repay the loan and these additional savings will be used to give her children a good education in English and will give her family a better standard of living.

loans.use: to add more varieties of fish and expand her fish shop in terms of size.

loans.name: Kukun

texts.ru: Кукун, 47 лет, замужем, мать 2 детей. У нее есть достаточно развитое хозяйство - 4 коровы, 4 овцы. Ежемесячная прибыль - около 11,000 сом (KGS). Кукун обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сомов (KGS) на покупку овец для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита она планирует направлять в дальнейшее развитие ее деятельности.
texts.en: Kukun is 47, married, and the mother of two children.  She has a rather well-developed farming business, with four cows and four sheep.  She makes close to 11,000 som (KGS) per month.  Kukun has turned to Bai Tushum and requested a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) to buy a few sheep and increase her livestock headcount.  She is planning to use the earnings from her loan to further develop her activity.

loans.use: to buy some sheep in order to increase her livestock headcount.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is a 60 years old, widowed and has five children to provide for. She is engaged in a rickshaw transport business to earn her living and be able to provide for her children needs. 

As a mother and a single mother of 5 children, she wants to give her children a good life. So she must increase her income to achieve this. Estrella decided to borrow a loan to buy spare parts to repair the rickshaw so that she can continue to cater for more passengers that will generate better income.

Estrella's plan for the future is to save money to sustain the needs of her children.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to repair her rickshaw.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is a married woman with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Rosalinda is 61 years old now.

Rosalinda has a candle making business in the Philippines. Rosalinda requested a PHP 6,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy wax, coloring, wood, and other supplies to use in her business.

Rosalinda has been in this business for 7 years. In the future, Rosalinda would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy wax, coloring, wood, and other supplies to use in her business.

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Estrelita works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling black pepper in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs.  Estrelita is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase more packs of black pepper to sell in her black pepper business.

Estrelita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more packs of black pepper to sell.

loans.name: Neria

texts.en:
Neria is 60 years old and married with six children.

Neria works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, home product care, and other groceries.

Neria has borrowed and paid back one loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 39 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Neria aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, home product care, and other groceries.

loans.name: Wenebel

texts.en:
Wenebel is 49 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Wenebel is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Wenebel has been raising pigs for 4 years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Rovelyn

texts.en:
Rovelyn is 36 years old and married with six children. With four children in school, Rovelyn works very hard to provide for them.

Rovelyn runs a personal product care business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like face powder, lotion, etc..

Rovelyn has been in this business for 8 years. 

In the future, Rovelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like face powder and lotion

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is 40 years old and married with four children.

Susana works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like snack foods, canned goods, beverages, home products, and other groceries.

Susana has borrowed and paid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her general store for 10 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Susana aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like snack food, canned goods, beverages, home products, and other groceries

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is 53 years old and married with seven children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, noodles, eggs, soap, milk, etc.

Lourdes has borrowed and paid 4 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 6 years and also earns an income from rice sales.

She aspires to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, noodles, eggs, soap and milk

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en: Jonathan is a 46-year-old married man with 10 children, 5 of them attend school.in Kasese, Uganda. Jonathan has been selling fish for over 10 years. He  also deals in  brick laying as a side job. Jonathan began his fish business to improve his family's economic position, especially to pay school fees for his children. However, he has a challenge of limited capital. His desire is to diversify his business and start up anther income generating activity. Jonathan requests a loan to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Raelyn

texts.en:
Raelyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a pig farm in the Philippines.

Raelyn has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been in this business for 10 years now.

Raelyn would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Ilorna

texts.en:
Ilorna is 48 years old and married. Ilorna works very hard to provide for them.

Ilorna runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, home product care, and other groceries.

Ilorna has been in this business for 20 years. 

In the future, Ilorna would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, home product care, and other groceries.

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with six children.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks of household goods to sell like spices, sugar, milk, etc.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like buying and selling rice.

Purita dreams that one day she will be able to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of household goods to sell like spices, sugar, milk.

loans.name: Shiba Shg-B Group

texts.en:
Dhanamani, the one standing to the left, is a member of Shiba SHG-B Group. She is 34 years old and has two children, both of whom are teenagers. Her husband Kumara works in the field of agriculture earning 5,000 INR per month. 

Dhanamani intends to send her kids to better schools and, subsequently, a good college so that they can have the opportunity to generate a better livelihood for themselves. However, she cannot achieve that solely on the income of her husband. Therefore, she joined Shiba SHG-B along with her group member Duti to take a small loan and expand the agriculture business with her husband. 

Dhanmani, along with her group member, has requested a loan of 36,000 INR from which she will use her portion to buy seeds and fertilizers and to pay labour charges so she will be able to produce more outputs and save more. This will come in handy on a monthly basis to save for the future of her kids.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers and pay the labour charges.

loans.name: Laureana

texts.en:
Laureana is a married woman with six children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Laureana is 52 years old now.

Laureana has a business buying and selling hollow blocks in the Philippines. Laureana requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more hollow blocks to sell.

Laureana has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Laureana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more hollow blocks to sell.

loans.name: Shiba Shg-A Group

texts.en:
Daimati, 29, standing to the right is a married adult with one young son. She is a native of Koraput district, which is located in the western region of Odisha, India. She is known for being a hardworking and responsible woman with a strong desire for self-improvement. 

She is a small business owner who manages her own businesses, which include a cosmetics business and a general store where she sells products for daily use, such as basic grains, soap, detergents, soda, ice, bread, eggs, and frozen goods, among other items. Her merchandise is high quality and affordable for her customers. She buys her merchandise from markets and distributors from the region. She has loyal customers as well as irregular customers. She started her business with her savings from her previous work. She started with a small window and little by little she invested until she has a well-stocked store. She starts her day very early, opening the doors to her business and tending to her customers. 

One of her dreams is to expand her business so that she can increase her profits and make some repairs to her home. For these reasons, Daimati along with her group member Sushila is seeking a loan of 36,000 INR. She will use her portion of the loan amount to invest in working capital for her businesses by purchasing basic goods such as rice, beans, cosmetics, snacks, etc. By increasing the size of her business, she can purchase products at better prices, stock her store better with the products that are in highest demand, and in so doing, increase her income and offer her customers better prices.

loans.use: to purchase basic goods for her general store and cosmetic shop like rice, beans, snacks, detergents and other cosmetic items.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle is a 38-year-old married woman with five children, one of which is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Annabelle has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her business.

Annabelle has been in this business for 2 years. In the future, Annabelle would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Shiba Shg-E Group

texts.en:
Tula,the lady to the left, is a 46-year-old featured borrower of the Shiba SHG-E group. She lives in a small village in Koraput district of Odisha state, India. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a self-employed bicycle mechanic who sells bicycle spare parts and installs them. 

Tula has been a tailor since 2009 and has managed to survive off the tailoring business since then. She specializes mostly in ladies dresses such as blouses and salwar-kurta. She has been helping her husband with household obligations. 

Before coming to People’s Forum, business for her was low. This was because she did not have enough capital to buy materials to meet her demand. She also lacked business management skills that she obtained from the training offered at People’s Forum. With her savings, she also purchased an industrial sewing machine for her business, and this has enabled her to achieve better efficiency and effectiveness. 

Tula along with her group member Dayamani, has requested for a loan amount of 36,000 INR. With the Kiva loan, she hopes to get more materials and an assistant so she can be able to take on bigger jobs as her business is expanding. She wishes to one day have her own house where she can live with her family.

loans.use: to purchase more materials for her tailoring business and hire an assistant to help her in her business.

loans.name: Shiba Shg-D Group

texts.en:
Rukamani is a 41-year-old woman from Koraput district in Odisha, India. She is the one standing to the left. Rukamani is married and has one daughter. Her husband has been suffering from a serious disease for the last two years and she is the only one earning in her family. 

Rukamani is a member of a self-help group with one more member that has been in vegetable cultivation and selling business for the last year. They also buy vegetables in bulk from other farmers to resell. The name of the group is ‘Shiba SHG-D’. Rukamani earns a good profit from the business as the group has been trained by Peoples Forum on how to improve their vegetable cultivation and selling business. As such, they can always produce all types of vegetables for the local markets and non-local markets. 

Rukamani and her group member Laxmi have asked for a loan of 36,000 INR. Rukamani’s share of the loan will help her to buy more vegetables in bulk to resell. Rukamani aspires to earn more income, as well as to repay this loan and support her husband's health and children's educational needs. Rukamani thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables in bulk in order to resell.

loans.name: Juditha

texts.en:
Juditha is 40 years old, married with five children, four of whom are in school.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of household goods to sell.

Juditha has borrowed and paid back 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and also earns an income from fishing.

She aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of household goods to sell.

loans.name: Jyotsna

texts.en:
Jyotsna is a rural housewife of 47 years, living in Ruidanga village in Alilpurduar district of West Bengal with her family. She is a mother of two sons and one daughter. Her elder son works in the police department on a basis of daily wages and other two are studying in college. Jyotsna, in her young age, was compelled to drop out of school due to her family's financial insufficiency.  So she is determined to provide the best education to her children, which is what they deserve. Her husband is a farmer by profession.

Her son, 23-year-old Prashanta, is pursuing Bachelor degree in education from Ghoksadanga College in Falakata. He has recently started attending classes at college. Furthermore, he wants to join the coaching centers to get better results in his exams. But his father is facing problems to pay the fees and purchase the text books all together at the same time due to his low income. 

So his mother Jyotsna has taken out a loan from BJS, a Kiva partner. She wants to utilize the loan to pay college fees, private tuition fees and purchase all necessary educational materials, so that her son can get ahead with his studies without any interruption.

Jyotsna and her son Prashanta (in the picture) are very much grateful to BJS and Kiva for their loan.

loans.use: To pay for her son's educational expenses.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy metal sheeting, wood and nails to change the roof of her house.

loans.name: Sebastian

texts.es:
Con grandes propósitos en la vida es Sebastián de 31 años de edad, es casado y tiene una linda familia de cuatro hijos de las edades entre 1 y 10 años, ellos viven en una comunidad de Sololá.
 Para Sebastián su familia es su mayor prioridad es por ello que para obtener sus ingresos y mantenerlos trabaja como ayudante de albañil, él tiene quince años de realizar esta labor, Sebastián es uno de los pocos padres  de familia que se preocupa por las necesidades de su querida familia y ahora se ha dado cuenta que una de las más fundamentales es la remodelación del techo de su casa, aunque una de sus dificultades es no contar con el dinero suficiente para poder comprar las láminas, por tal motivo solicita un crédito que lo utilizara para cubrir esta necesidad.
El gran sueño de Sebastián es mejorar su casa para que su familia tenga un hogar  digno.
texts.en:
Sebastian, 31, has great goals in life.  He is married and has a beautiful family of four children between the ages of one and 10.  They live in a community in Solola.

Sebastian's main priority is his family and he works as a bricklayer's assistant to earn an income to support them.  For 15 years he has been working in his job.  Sebastian is one of the few fathers who worries about the needs of his beloved family and now he has realized that one of the most basic needs is the repair of the roof of his house.  But one of his difficulties is not having enough money to buy the metal sheeting.  Therefore he is requesting a loan to cover this need.

Sebastian's greatest goal is to improve the house so his family has a decent place to live.

loans.use: To buy metal sheeting for the roof of her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy metal sheeting, beams, sand, cement, nails, etc. to improve her home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and material to make clothes to sell

loans.name: Mervel

texts.en:
In the Philippines, “sari-sari” stores are everywhere. Sari-sari (a Filipino term for variety) stores sell different products like biscuits, candies, canned goods, noodles, toiletries and many other items that are needed for individual’s daily living. This is considered as one of the most common businesses built by ordinary people since it provides necessities for the general public.

Mervel was encouraged to run this kind of enterprise. He is 29-year-old and single, residing in Oton, Iloilo. Despite his single status, his responsibilities cannot be underrated. Single people in the Philippines are expected to support their parents and siblings. But sometimes his income becomes unstable due to stiff competition and delayed payments of his customers. He longs to make his business more competitive by adding wide selections in his inventory. He needs PHP 15,000 supplementary capital to attain this. He wishes for your generous assistance and prays that more blessings be returned to you. 

He hopes that his store will progress in due time. Personally, he also prays to have his own family to whom he can dedicate all his efforts. Marvel meets with his co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of his life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more supplies to add to his store inventory

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl works hard to support her family. Sheryl is married and has a rice sales business in the Philippines.

She has requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to purchase more sacks of rice to sell.

Sheryl has been in this business for 7 years now, and also earns additional income from raising pigs.

In the future, Sheryl would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Maa Narayani Shg-A Group

texts.en:
Bimala, the lady standing on the right hand side is 34 years old and lives in the village of Neheru Pali in Koraput district. She is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 4 years, Bimala has been working hard to manage her poultry business.

To help expand her business, Bimala along with her group member Phulokumari has requested a loan of 36,000 INR from Kiva’s partner Peoples Forum.  Bimala will use her loan amount to procure more chickens to increase her stock for dealing them. This will help Bimala to generate greater profits and manage to add even more chickens which will result in an increase of her stock and an improvement of her sales. 

Bimala hopes that in the future she will be able to have more eggs which will be enough to bring her financial sustainability.

loans.use: to procure more chickens so as to increase her revenue.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock her grocery store with rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, matches, oil, ice, fruit, vegetables and juices.

loans.name: Balcon 3 Group

texts.es:
Daniela es una mujer de 25 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene 3 hijos uno recién nacido de 2 meses y de 2 y 3 años, y su negocio es la venta de pan.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, dedicada, constante, amable, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la localidad ‘El torno’, comunidad que en los últimos años ha experimentado un crecimiento en su demografía debido a la emigración de la población del interior del país, el clima se caracteriza por ser sub tropical, al estar comprendido entre las llanuras y los valles mesotérmicos, aunque se registran vientos fuertes y lluvias tormentosas en ciertas épocas del año.
Daniela es de tez morena, ojos marrones, cabello castaño largo lo usa amarrado por detrás, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que se habla en el lugar y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (esta sentada). Su vida la comparte con su pareja que trabaja repartiendo pan, viven en una casa propiedad de la familia construida de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de cemento que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. La necesidad de pagar los gastos médicos y posnatales de sus 3 pequeños hijos la obligó a formar una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de jugos naturales, venta de artículos de librería, venta de ropa de segunda mano, venta de comida, artesanía en tela, elaboración de sombreros de saó y taller de llaves, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus actividades. Su negocio es la elaboración y venta de pan tradicional, como; pan de arroz (a base de harina de arroz), pan de maíz (a base de harina de maíz), pan de leche (a base de leche), Bizcochos de trigo (Bollitos duros de harina de trigo) y otros. Actividad que realiza en un cuarto de su casa habilitado como panadería, su esposo se encarga de la venta de forma ambulante a diferentes tiendas y puestos de venta, “trabajo desde mi hogar, mi trabajo comienza en la madrugada cuando mi hijos duermen y tengo el resto del día para poder atenderlos…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que puede atender a su familia y trabajar, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de harina para hornear continuamente y llegar a más clientes. Su sueño es ver crecer a sus hijos sanos y fuertes, ella desea realizar la compra de diferentes tipos de harina por quintal. Esta es la 2 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 4 años que viene realizando esta actividad. 
Es por esos motivos que Daniela solicita un préstamo para la compra de variedades de harinas para hornear diferentes tipos de pan diariamente y cuidar a sus hijos el resto del tiempo.
texts.en:
Daniela, 25, lives with her partner and three children: a newborn baby who is two months old, a 2-year-old and a 3-year-old.  She sells bread for a living.  She is a good mother and entrepreneur who is dedicated, consistent, kind, responsible and very hard working.  She works in the town of "El Torno" which is a community that has experienced demographic growth over the last few years due to immigration of people from further inland in the country.  The climate is subtropical as is it between the plains and mesothermic valleys, although there are strong winds and thunderstorms at certain times of year.

Daniela has a dark complexion, brown eyes, long brown hair that she ties back, is of short height and has a robust physique.  Her mother tongue is Guaraní which is spoken locally and she uses Spanish for general purposes and in her business (she is the one seated in the photo).  She and her partner, who delivers bread, live in their own brick and concrete house which has a metal roof and concrete floor.  They have running water, electricity and a sewage system.  The need to pay for postnatal medical expenses for her three small children is what obliged her to set up a communal bank which includes businesses such as selling natural juices, stationery goods, second-hand clothing, food, fabric crafts, "Sao" hat manufacture and a keysmith.  The loan is to improve the group's businesses.

Daniela makes and sells traditional bread such as rice flour bread, corn bread, milk bread, wheat cakes and others.  She works out of a room in her home that was remodeled into a bakery.  Her husband is the one who delivers the bread to different stores and stalls.  "I work from home and start in the wee morning hours while my children sleep.  I have the rest of the day to care for them..." she says.  The advantage of her business is that she can attend to both family and work responsibilities.  The disadvantage is the lack of capital to buy flour on a continuous basis and reach out to more customers.  Her dream is to raise healthy, strong children.  

She wants to buy different types of flour by the quintal.  This is her second loan through the institution in the four years she has been in business.  Her aim is to make different kinds of bread every day and care for her children the rest of the time.

loans.use: To buy a variety of flours to bake different breads daily and to to care for her children the rest of the time.

loans.name: Edson

texts.en:
Edson used the previous loan to buy drugs to sell. He is a farmer growing food crops like maize and ground nuts owning a salon alongside running a drug shop to boost his income. 

He is faced with challenges of less capital, that hinder expansion of his business as he plans to fully engage himself in commercial agriculture. Edson has asked for a loan to prepare land for tomato growing.

loans.use: to prepare land for growing tomatoes

loans.name: Gyulnara

texts.en:
Gyulnara and her husband live in Harjis village of Syuniq region and run their farming business.  Their daughter is married and lives separately with her husband's family. Gyulnara's son is a migrant worker, she and her husband are alone with their farm.
 
Their livestock is big (including three cows, calves, 45 sheep, hens and 10 turkeys). In the farm they also cultivate wheat, haricots and potatoes. Besides farming Gyulnara also works at local cheese making factory to get additional income for supporting family's living. 

Gyulanara asks lenders to help her with the development of the farm. She plans to purchase two calves and forage for feeding the livestock. 
This is Gyulnara's second loan. Unfortunately, the first loan, which she got from local financial institutions previously, was very difficult to return back, and Gyulnara faced some difficulties. However, thanks to her hard work during recent times, she and her husband were able to run their agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that they will be able to cover the monthly payments. 

So, Gyulnara has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Please support this family's efforts of having a profitable and sustainable farm.

loans.use: to pay for two calves and forage for feeding the livestock

loans.name: Kampouy's Group

texts.en:
Kampouy is 32 years old, living in Battambang province and she has three children. Nowadays, she earns income to support her family’s living condition via working for others for a fee and growing oranges. She has been with both businesses for twelve years. She can earn income around 36,000KHR per day, but she is able to save about 15,000KHR each day after offsetting her business expenses. Low crop yields are still the main challenge for her business. Previous loans have helped her to keep children in school. 

This is sixth loan cycle for her with Kiva loan, VisionFund. In a group of two members, she will take her entire new loan portion to buy fertilizer to support her cash crop. She hopes that this loan will help her business to earn more income to timely expand her current business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to support her cash crop, growing oranges

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a single woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past five years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition from other retail operators.

With the loan, she is requesting she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Sinoeurn's Group

texts.en:
Sinoeurn, 34, lives with family members in a rural village of Battambang province and a mother of five children. To support on her family’s living, she grows rice and sells vegetables are the main source of income. She has involved this business for 12 years and she can save her daily income about 19,700KHR per day. 

This is ninth cycles for Sinoeurn with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and she has fully repaid back her past loans successfully. For her past loans, Sinoeurn can update her family’s living and keeps her children in school as well. She leads a group of two members to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will use her entire loan portion to buy various kinds of vegetables for her new selling business. She hopes that her new business can gain her income to update her living get better than before.

loans.use: to buy various kinds of vegetables for her new selling business.

loans.name: Nuon's Group

texts.en:
An old woman from Battambang province, Nuon is 64 years old and a mother of six dependent children. She grows rice as the main source of income and works for others for a fee. Moreover, she can get extra income via cows-raising. Her bad yield last year was caused by drought. She has been involved in this business for 12 years and she can save her income about 21,700KHR per day. 

For Nuon, this is her eighth cycle with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and she has repaid back her past loans successfully. With her past loan, it makes her family’s living better than before. She leads a group of two to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will use her loan to buy fertilizer, seed and pay for plowing fee to improve her rice farm get good yield. She hopes that she can get more income to expand her farmland bigger than before.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seed and pay for plowing fee to improve her rice farm to get good yield.

loans.name: Adán Ignacio

texts.es:
Adán es un hombre de 45 años de edad, es casado vive junto a linda familia en una comunidad de Sololá, él cuenta que con el crédito logro realizar la remodelación de su casa y que ahora su familia vive en mejores condiciones de vida, Adán viendo las necesidades de su familia nuevamente solicita un crédito que lo invertirá en la remodelación de una parte de su casa que aún se encuentra en muy malas condiciones y así contar con un hogar más presentable.
El gran sueño de Adán es realizar mejoras en su casa para que su familia cuente con mas comodidad.
texts.en:
Adán is a 45-year-old man. He is married and lives with his lovely family in a community in Sololá. He says that with the last loan he was able to carry out refurbishments to his house and now his family lives in better living conditions. 

Seeing his family's needs, Adán is again asking for a loan which he will invest in refurbishing a part of his house which is still in a very poor condition, so he can have a more presentable home.

Adán's big dream is to carry out improvements to his home so that his family is more comfortable.

loans.use: to buy materials to refurbish his house.

loans.name: Celia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Celia, de 49 años de edad, estudio hasta noveno grado, porque sus padres son de escasos recursos y no le pudieron continuar ayudando, es madre soltera de un niño de 1 año de edad, por problemas familiares se separo de él padre de su hijo, pero sin embargo él aún le apoya con los gastos.- Actualmente, ella vive en casa de sus padres y le ayuda a su papá con las labores agrícolas, ya que su papá ya es de avanzada edad y se le dificulta hacer los trabajos pesados. 

Celia, aprendió a trabajar en el campo desde que tenia 17 años de edad, su padre le enseño esta labor para que fuera independiente; ahora Celia, trabaja un área de 14,000 metros cuadrados de tierra con su padre, la cual está a un costado de su vivienda, por lo que las labores agrícolas las realizan por la mañana.

Celia, utilizara el préstamo para comprar fertilizantes, sulfato de amonio y herbicidas para su cultivo de maíz, con ello pretende que su cultivo sea más productivo y pueda obtener un mayor ingreso al momento de su venta. 

Celia, sueña con construir una casa de sistema mixto, ya que donde viven actualmente está construido de lámina y bahareque por lo que es muy insegura, también desea que su hijo estudie una carrera universitaria.
texts.en:
Celia, who is 49 years old, only studied as far as ninth grade because her parents have a limited income and they could not continue to help her. She is a single mother with a one-year-old child. She separated from her son's father because of family problems but he still helps her with her expenses. 

Currently she lives in her parents' house and she helps her father with his agricultural work, since he is of an advanced age and it is difficult for him to do the heavy jobs. Celia learnt how to work in the fields from when she was 17 years old. Her father taught her the work so she could be independent. Now she works an area of 14,000 square metres of land with her father. The land is at one side of their home and so they do the agricultural tasks in the morning. 

Celia will use the loan to buy fertilizers, ammonium sulphate and herbicides for her corn crop. With this she hopes her crop will give a better yield and she will be able to make more income when she sells it. 

Celia dreams of building a mixed system house because the one they live in currently is made of wattle and daub with metal sheeting and so is very insecure. She also wants her son to study for a university degree.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, ammonium sulphate and herbicides for her corn crop.

loans.name: Moteng G3 Group

texts.en: Matsoe-peea is a 50 year old mother of 5 aged between 13-26 years. She not only takes care of her children but has to take care of her elderly aunt who has become bed ridden due to old age and illness. Matsoe-peea lives in a small traditional hut that is not well ventilated, nor warms up well in winter. She works long hours to ensure there is enough food for her family.She has to wake up very early, between 3am and 4am, during the week to start preparing the fire for cooking breakfast, heating water and warming the house for her young children who go to school and help bath her elderly aunt. Collecting firewood, setting up the fire and doing the actual cooking demands a lot of her time. Temperatures in the Lesotho highlands are never really high; winters can get very cold and often  Matsoe-peea has to start the fire inside her hut. Starting a fire releases smog and smoke which when inhaled in large quantities over a period of time can lead to lung diseases, eye problems and in the worst case to death. In these circumstances, life for women like  Matsoe-peea has been very difficult. ACE has requested a loan from Kiva lenders, in order to be able to sell on credit clean cook stoves which provide Matsoe-peea and 11 other people from her village, who are living in the same circumstances the chance of cooking in a way that does not harm them and their families, and that does not require a lot of wood, which is hard to find in Lesotho, nor expensive paraffin and gas . This stove can be started with the use of very little, readily available biomass like dry twigs and dry cow dung that do not require lengths of time to collect. It does not produce smoke while burning, thus making it safe to be used inside the homes. This stove comes with a solar panel for charging the battery which runs the fan in the stove, a USB port for charging phones and a mini LED lamp. A life improving package for these women. This stove saves them time to be with their family, saves energy, eliminates the element of toxic inhalation, house burning and has given them the freedom to have a better lit home to see better in the evening while cooking and enables children to do their homework. For stove info please check www.africancleanenergy.com

loans.use: To be able to pay for the ACE stoves which improves their lives in terms of health, cost of fuel and the time they spend collecting firewood.

loans.name: Sankoe Group

texts.en:
Mathabang is a 56 year old mother of 3 children aged between 16-24 years. She not only takes care of her children but has to take care of her three young grandchildren aged 7 and 5 and 4 who have lost both their parents. 

Mathabang lives in a traditional hut that is not well ventilated, nor warms up well in winter. She works long hours to ensure there is enough food for her children and grandchildren, some of whom are going to school and only help her in the field on Saturdays and Sundays. She has to wake up very early, between 3am and 4am, during the week to start preparing the fire for cooking breakfast, heating water and warming the house for all the children before they go to school. 

Collecting firewood, setting up the fire and doing the actual cooking demands a lot of her time. Temperatures in the Lesotho highlands are never really high; winters can get very cold and often Mathabang has to start the fire inside her hut. Starting a fire releases smog and smoke which when inhaled in large quantities over a period of time can lead to lung diseases, eye problems and in the worst case to death. In these circumstances, life for women like Mathabang has been very difficult. 

Mathabang has requested a loan from Kiva lenders, in order to be able to purchase clean cook stoves which provide Mathabang and 9 other people from her village, who are living in the same circumstances, the chance of cooking in a way that does not harm them and their families, and that does not require a lot of wood, which is hard to find in Lesotho, nor expensive paraffin and gas. This stove can be started with the use of very little, readily available biomass like dry twigs and dry cow dung that do not require lengths of time to collect. It does not produce smoke while burning, thus making it safe to be used inside the homes. This stove comes with a solar panel for charging the battery which runs the fan in the stove, a USB port for charging phones and a mini LED lamp. A life improving package for these women. This stove saves them time to be with their family, saves energy, eliminates the element of toxic inhalation, house burning and has given them the freedom to have a better lit home to see better in the evening while cooking and enables children to do their homework. For stove info please check www.africancleanenergy.com

loans.use: To be able to pay for the ACE cook stove which will improve her life in terms of health, cost of fuel and the time she spends collecting firewood.

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es: Angélica tiene 69 años de edad, habita en casa de su propiedad y se dedica a la venta de fruta pelada y en cascara desde hace mucho tiempo de forma ambulante en las cercanías de su comunidad. Ella es una mujer ejemplar quien hace todo lo que esté en sus manos para llevar el sustento y mantener la economía  del hogar. Angélica deseosa de mejorar su vivienda  obtuvo un crédito anteriormente el cual debido a que se enfermo gravemente se vio en la obligación y la  necesidad de redireccionar el dinero para la compra de medicamentos que ayudaron a recuperar su salud. Por lo anterior y con el propósito de realizar las mejoras en su vivienda ella solicita este nuevo crédito a FUSAI para la compra de: cemento, arena,grava y ladrillo para encementar el piso y construir un pequeño muro para de esta forma evitar que en tiempos de lluvia el agua se le meta a su casa en la parte del corredor.
texts.en:
Angélica is 69 years old, lives in a house of her own, and has made a living in her area as a traveling fruit vendor for many years.
She is an exemplary woman who does everything that she can to support her household's needs.
Angélica wanted to improve her home and obtained a previous loan to do that. Unfortunately, she fell gravely ill and had to repurpose the money to buy much-needed medication instead.
Therefore, she asks for a second loan in order to finally improve her house. She will use the funds to buy cement, sand, gravel, and bricks to lay a concrete floor and build a small wall. The latter will prevent water from coming into the house when it rains.

loans.use: to buy materials to improve her house.

loans.name: Juana Cecilia

texts.es:
Juana, de 32 años de edad, logro estudiar hasta noveno grado, está acompañada con el padre de sus dos hijos de 6 y 3 años de edad, ella vive con sus padres ya que no cuenta con vivienda propia. 

Juana, desde muy joven aprendio a hacer pan dulce gracias a su madre, para que fuera independiente y en el futuro poder valerse de si misma; tiene 10 años de tener su negocio, al igual que el trabajo con sus cultivos; ella comercializa su producto en el centro del cantón y en sus alrededores y las labores agrícolas las realiza con su pareja por la mañana y por las tardes sale a vender pan por el cantón. 

Juana, utilizara el crédito para comprar insumos agrícolas como formula, urea y también herbicidas para limpiar su milpa, con ello espera que su cultivo sea más productivo y pueda tener un mejor precio en el mercado.

Juana, quiere ampliar su negocio y tener un horno industrial porque donde hace el pan es en un horno de leña y tiene que prepararlo con mucha anticipación antes de hacerlo, también quiere obtener un mejor rendimiento de sus cultivos y de esta forma poder obtener mejores ingresos al momento de su venta para poder dar a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Juana, 32, managed to study up to ninth grade.  She lives with the father of her two children, ages 6 and 3.  She lives with her parents because she doesn't have her own home.

Juana learned to make pan dulce [sweet bread] at a very young age, thanks to her mother, so she could be independent and self-sufficient.  She has had her business for 10 years, and she also has crops.  She sells her product in the center of the canton and the surrounding area; she does the agricultural work with her partner in the morning and goes out to sell bread in the canton in the afternoon.

Juana will use the loan to buy agricultural inputs such as formula and urea as well as herbicides to clear her field.  With this she hopes her crop will be more productive and she can get a better price in the market.

Juana wants to expand her business and get an industrial oven because now she makes the bread in a firewood oven and has to get it ready way ahead of time.  She also wants a better yield from her crops so she can earn more income when she sells and give her children a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs such as formula, urea, and herbicides to clear her field

loans.name: Tariq’S Group

texts.en:
Tariq and his group members are farmers by occupation. They are permanent residents of Khan Musalman, a far-flung village in district Gujranwala in Pakistan.

He and his group members have a small land holding in the surrounding of the village where they cultivate wheat and rice to feed their families. Both of these crops are the sole source of earning for the group members. 

Among other challenges faced by the farmers of this group, most prominent is the lack of funds to finance their agricultural inputs required to cultivate their rice crop. They are eagerly looking for a loan to finance their urgently required agricultural inputs. This loan will help them to increase their crop productivity and enable them to expand their cultivated land.

loans.use: To purchase agriculture inputs i.e. fertilizer, pesticide, seeds and fuel etc.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica hails in the town of Talibon, Bohol.  She is 50-year old married woman with three children. Her oldest child is 25 and the youngest is 12. She operates a sari-sari(variety) store. She sells commodities ranging from eggs, powdered milk, sugar, noodles, edible oil, beverages, canned goods, soap and soft drinks. Her husband has also an income that could help to defray the family's expenses. 

She is asking for a loan to purchase  groceries such as seasonings, assorted canned goods and toiletries.  These will improve the content of her store and also enables more buyers to come. With these, her earnings will augment and able to provide the basic needs of her children. She could now able to handle her finances as well.

Veronica is hoping that she could manage her sari-sari store business successfully to become financially stable.

loans.use: to purchase  groceries

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 37-year-old single lady who decided few months ago to open her own clothing shop. She has nine years of experience in this domain, as she used to work in a clothing shop. She is a hard worker and ambitious lady who is trying hard to develop her business to attract more customers and satisfy their needs.

Today, Fatima is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to increase her merchandise with new collection of summer clothes. She hopes to expand her business more in the future to increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to increase her merchandise with a new collection of summer clothes

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
Mylene comes from from the province of General Trias, Cavite, Philippines. She is 37 y/o and happily married to Arnulfo, a security guard and are blessed with two children of which one is already in college and the other one is still in the High School Level. The couple help each other to provide for their children's education and their daily needs.

To help augment their income Mylene maintains a small general store for seven years already. Although there are other general store around her area which competes for her sales she is still glad with the good turnout of her store as it really helps meet her family's everyday needs and school needs of her children. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of Php 700 a day. 

To help her continue operations of her store she is requesting an Php 19000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items like canned goods, coffee, eggs, instant noodles, beverages etc. As she is faced with fierce competition from the nearby stores she is challenged to offer more kinds of essential food items on her store to attract more customers. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her. She values her store so much since it is where she gets the funds to support her children's school needs.

Mylene aims to grow her small store into a big grocery store. Her simple dream is to see all her children go to College. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional grocery items, beverages and toiletries to sell.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael and his wife have worked on their current farm situated in the outskirts of Chuka town, Kenya, since 2010. Since then, their farm and family have grown in more ways than one. In 2010, the couple started working on a run-down farm. Today, they are making money off the poultry and dairy animals they raise and also the different variety of crops that they grow. Michael has further invested in a side business to supplement the meager income he earns from farming. 

Michael loves to dairy farm, especially since it was always a life goal of his to be a farmer. His wife understands this and together they joined hearts and hands to make the farm’s success to date happen. 

Michael is seeking a loan to purchase a pedigree dairy cow. There are more than 100 cattle breeds in Kenya. However, not all are good producers of milk. In fact, very few are. Cattle aside, the tastes and preferences of milk in the market is really growing diverse in Kenya. Taking milk is no longer a matter of pouring it into our cereal bowl, adding it to our coffee, or drinking it straight from the glass, we now have preferences in the type of milk we drink. Today, milk consumers are spoiled for choice: In the market, we have old-fashioned cow’s milk and lactose-free milk, not to mention non-dairy options such as soy, almond, rice and coconut milk. It takes dairy masters like Michael to pick these shifts in the market and adopt ingenious techniques in farming to ensure that their product qualities adapt to the changes in consumer preference. 

Buying a pedigree cow goes to show how Michael is keen on controlling lame levels in his dairy cattle. He considers breeding to be the core of his overall strategy of ensuring that milk quantity is way above average and the milk quality is second to none in the market. He anticipates that feeding will be his highest cost of milk production. This, to him, is accepted because to get cows that milk well and remain healthy, they have to be fed properly. Your loan will make a significant difference to Michael's farm profitability. 

The couple will make use the returns from this investment to pay for the loan, pay for their children’s education and the rest will be reinvested in the business. It has always been their ambition to share their passion about farming with their two children. They hope the kids will be thrilled to join the business of running the family farm.

loans.use: To buy a high pedigree cow to expand her dairy herd for greater milk yields

loans.name: Teofista

texts.en:
Teofista is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a soft drinks retailer business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to purchase additional cases of soft drinks to sell for her soft drinks retailer business.

Teofista has been in this business for 15 years. Teofista earns more income from food vending.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional cases of soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
She is Maria Elena, 56 years old, married to Romeo, an LGU worker. They have children, two of whom are still studying in college. The cost of college education is usually pocket draining, hence Maria Elena raises hogs in their backyard to add income for her family. It is a promising enterprise but the return of investment takes several months. She has to advance considerable amount of capital before she earns her profit. As of now, her capital starts to drain and she still has small pigs to raise. 

She appeals for PhP 10,000 additional capital to buy more feeds, medicines and vitamins. In two to three weeks, she can already sell one fattened hog and she can surely restore her capital. Slowly, she expands her small pigpen hoping that someday it can grow into a big piggery that can supply more consumers in their community and nearby areas. She dreams of completing her children’s education that will pave the way to their brighter future. 

She shares her experiences and aspirations to her co-fellowship* members at CCT Credit Cooperative in Oton, Iloilo. They regularly meet every week to share stories about their life and businesses and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more feeds, medicines and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.en:
Direct selling business is common in the Philippines especially for housewives who want to be productive and are willing to supplement the lack of family resources. Working people who want to earn extra money usually engage in this business also. It’s easy to venture into direct selling business since it typically requires low capital to begin with. Then the entrepreneur or direct selling representative will just enhance the business by expanding her network and target consumers and proper rolling of capital.

Ninfa of Oton, Iloilo is a direct selling representative who sells Personal Collection products. She is married to Roldan who is currently unemployed. It’s just good that one of her children is already working and extends financial help to the family. But they still struggle with their everyday expenses. This is why Ninfa aspires to improve her business with the aid of additional capital amounting to PhP 10,000. 

She will use it to buy more Personal Collection products that she can sell to her friends, neighbors and other network. She’s positive that this additional capital will give her more profit. Her dream is to have a stable space or a showroom for her business someday. She also desires for good health, brighter future for her children and harmonious relationship among her family. 

She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God. *All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more Personal Collection products

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
This is Emelyn and she's a sari-sari (variety) store owner in Oton, Iloilo. She's been running her store business for eight years now. She already experienced various circumstances that really tested her faith. There were times when her capital was almost drained due to huge collectibles. Some of her neighbors pay weeks or months later for the goods they get from her store. But Emelyn remained strong, because this is her way of assisting her foreman husband, Jeobert, in providing for their children’s needs.

Sari-sari store is comparable to a convenience store, but it’s smaller and has limited products commonly used by an individual everyday. Examples of these products are sachets of toiletries, snack items, canned goods, instants, candies, beverages and other commodities. It’s quite advantageous for the people in the community to have an accessible variety store to buy one candy, an egg, and so on. This is the reason why sari-sari stores proliferate in the communities of the Philippines. And the same reason why the competition becomes stiffer and stiffer. Customers prefer to buy from stores with wide selections and supplies. 

As you can see in the picture, Emelyn has very limited stocks. She appeals for your help through a loan worth PhP 25,000 which she can use to buy more supplies to enhance her store. She aspires to improve her sales to be able to earn more. She dreams that in the near future her business will grow in progress. She’s praying for a better life for her whole family. She wants her children to finish college and obtain a good and stable job.

 She meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. *All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is comprised of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more supplies to enhance her store

loans.name: Vatansilton

texts.en:
Vatansilton is a capable woman. She was born in southern part of Tajikistan in 1965 and is living in small town with her family. She has one child. She is challenged, goal-oriented and honest person. She has 26 years of practice working as a teacher, where she teaches beginning classes. She likes children and her activity. 

Now she is sick. However, she has no money to get the course of treatment at medical clinic. She appealed to IMON asking a loan to pay her treatment at medical clinic. She hopes to be supported and awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to pay for her treatment at a medical clinic

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
From Davao City, here is Erlinda, married to Miguel and they have children. She runs three enterprises: a welding shop where she employs two workers, a PUJ or public utility jeepney for passengers, and a limited motorcycle dealership. It’s very impressing how she manages her household and her three enterprises. For her, it’s just a matter of time management and proper balancing of budget. She says it’s not right to spend without limit, rather an individual should learn how to keep some amount in times of emergencies. For twenty years of business operation, she already gained enough knowledge and techniques on how to manage people and roll her capital. 

But there are situations that she cannot control like the increasing price of raw materials and equipments for welding, the gasoline-diesel hike, and other related matters. When their welding contract with construction site ends, their income also stops. As the household finance manager, Erlinda has to adjust her family’s everyday budget corresponding on her PUJ’s income and occasional motorcycle sales. 

To improve her welding business, she plans to expand her network of constructors. It would be best if she can get many welding contracts. She plans to buy new welding machine and more raw materials to get ready for possible higher demand. A loan amounting to PhP 35,000 would be very helpful. This may pave the way for her dream of putting up another shop in a more busy location. She hopes that she can bestow a stable business to her children after they finish their college education.

Erlinda is a compliant member of CCT Credit Cooperative and meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to inspire and strengthen each other through the Word of God. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy new welding machine and more raw materials for welding

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a married man with three kids, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
Richard operates a farming business of planting vegetables and tomatoes and selling them at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. He faces a challenge of high cost of seasonality to his place of operation. 

With the Kshs 15,000 he wants to purchase fertilizer and seedlings to use in his farming business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seedlings to use in his farming business.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is a humble worker who lives a life full of dreams, hopes and best wishes for her family. She is a smallholder farmer in the Kitale area of Kenya. In the past eight years, she has bred more than one dairy cows, developed her farm, and planted and sold a variety of crop. She says the secret to her success is thinking of farming as a way to make money, not just as a traditional way of life – adopting new technologies and methods, crop diversification, record-keeping and good planning also help. Winnie was unable to study to get a professional career because of the economic situation that her family faced. However, she never gave up and she has been practicing farming. 

Winnie always has a strong affinity for farming. Winnie also practices crop farming, but she has not been making good profits because of poor farming implements and that is why she is kindly seeking a loan to buy farm inputs. Through the loan, she will be able to buy high-quality seeds, good fertilizer and pesticides that she will use to greatly improve her crop production. Modern farming requires the use of modern techniques; using high-quality seeds will assure her of a bumper harvest and hence, increased profit levels. Winnie is visionary, and her goal for the season is to boost her crop production and be able to get more crop output than the previous year. All this can be achieved through lenders’ help and goodwill. Winnie believes that through the loan, she will turn around her family life and be able to give her children a solid educational background. This loan will be Winnie’s way out of poverty.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs, high-quality seeds, good fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with 4 children who attend school. She takes care of additional family members. She operates a grocery in a shop that she rents and has been in this business for the last 12 years and works seven days a week. She gets additional income from roasting maize. 

She has requested for a loan from MCDT – SACCO to buy sugar, rice, beans,soap, cooking oil, crates of soda,and flour. Her major challenge include high taxes on goods she sales . Her goal is to educate her children to the university level. She lives in her own house and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice, beans,soap,and crates of soda for her store

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 40 years old, married and has one child. To earn a living she has been engaged in a sari sari (variety) store business for five years already, earning income of PHP 5,200 a month. It really helps them in their daily needs. 

She aims to increase her income, so she decided to borrow a loan to buy more grocery items to sell, increasing her store inventory so that it will generate better income.

Maria's plan for the future is to save money from her business income to sustain the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide for supporting her rice fields.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cattle for fattening to sell.

loans.name: Kugonza

texts.en:
Kugonza lives in Hoima Uganda. He is aged 33 married with 3 children and two attend school. He rides a motor cycle for transport commonly known as Boda boda supplemented by incomes earned by operating a retail shop mainly selling of general merchandise like salt, sugar among other items. 

He hopes to expand his business and also educate his children. Kugonza is seeking for a loan facility to buy more stock items like salt,sugar and soap.

loans.use: to buy more stock items like salt,sugar and soap.

loans.name: Mahima Shg-B Group

texts.en:
This is 27-year-old Bimala standing to the left. She is married and has two children, aged 4 and 7. Bimala is from the village Kusumi of Koraput district and is the featured borrower of Mahima SHG-B.

In 2013, Bimala established her provision and grocery business. She began her business because she wanted to be self-employed and keep up her family livelihood. Her business is located in the outskirts of the city, and her main customers are both men and women. Working six days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 5,000 INR every month from this business.

Bimala, along with her fellow group member, would like a loan in the amount of 36,000 INR. Bimala requires a loan in order to buy more drinks, cooking oil, onions, rice and provisions for resale. She hopes that this loan will support her to increase the level of her additional income.

In the future, Bimala plans to raise more capital to build her own shop and stores for business expansion.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, cooking oil, onions and rice for the purpose of resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: el joven a quien se le ha pixeleado la cara por tener 22 años de edad y vivir en zona de alto riesgo, se dedica al cultivo de maíz y maicillo desde hace 4 años, vende sus productos en los alrededores de la zona donde el reside, el joven vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, insecticida, herbicida, etc. y mejorar el terreno que muestra en la fotografía para seguir con su trabajo y asi tener mejores ingresos económicos.
texts.en: The photo of this young man has been distorted because he lives in a high-risk part of the country.  The borrower, 22 years old, has been a farmer for 4 years.  He grows maize and maicillo and sells his crops locally.  He lives with his family in their own house.  He is applying for a loan that he will use to buy the supplies he needs--seeds, insecticides, etc.--to carry on his farming business.  The investment will help him to increase his earnings.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his farming business.

loans.name: Mahima Shg-C Group

texts.en:
Danamati, of age 37, is the featured borrower of Mahima SHG-C from the village Kusumi of Koraput district. She is married and the mother of four beautiful daughters. In the photo, Danamati is standing to the left-hand side. 

She sells food items in a small kiosk, and her customers characterize her as a friendly, charismatic woman. She manages her own business, and began selling food about seven years ago. Fortunately, she has the advantage of having a good location in a busy area. She gained her experience in the kitchen from her mother, so she has a broad knowledge of culinary management.

Danamati, along with her fellow group member, Tulashi, is requesting a loan amount of 36,000 INR.
