Rufina is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with four children, one of whom is in school.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like sardines, noodles, soap, etc. to sell.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like fish vending.

Rufina dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like sardines, noodles, soap, etc. to sell

loans.name: Protea Group

texts.en:
Sophia is in her mid-30s, married, and has got one boy who is still small. For two years now she has had a shop selling stationery (books, pens, pencils and other school and office stuff). She also provides M-pesa service at the same place. Sophia works at her business from 09 am to 09 pm per working day and is able to make a good profit each month. 

This is her second credit request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans, paid back successfully, to buy business stationery. Sophia received profits which she used to plow back into her business. In the coming years, she would like to improve her shop with more stationery and other demanded services like Tigo-pesa and Airtel money. 

She will use this loan to recharge her M-pesa fault and service more people. 

The credit will be shared among her group, PROTEA, consisting of two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to recharge her M-pesa fault and service more people.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha, who is in her early 30's, is married with two children who are in school. Asha has been running her restaurant business for seven years and she works from 5:00am to 6:00pm each working day. She makes a fair profit from her business. 

This will be Asha's fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to stock her restaurant with cooking supplies (e.g., sacks of rice, baking flour, maize flour, beans, sugar) and to buy cooking oil. She managed to successfully pay back all her previous loans. She used her profits to finish building her house and cover household expenses. 

Asha will use this loan to buy 5 bags of charcoal and cooking ingredients for her mamalishe. Her dream is to open another successful business. She will be held accountable for paying back the loan as per the schedule.

loans.use: to buy 5 bags of charcoal and cooking ingredients for her mamalishe.

loans.name: El Mirador Group

texts.es:
REVISADO
La comunidad mexiquense de donde es originario el grupo El Mirador conserva rasgos de la cultura mazahua como la vestimenta, lengua, música y danza. Su economía gira entorno a la agricultura, sobretodo en el cultivo del maíz, y de igual forma a la elaboración de artesanías ya que las mujeres mazahuas se caracterizan por ser las mejores artesanas de la región.
   Doña Julia es una mujer trabajadora, proviene de una familia muy numerosa cuyos valores mantiene para transmitirlos a sus propios hijos. Por cierto tiempo trabajó en la Ciudad de México como empleada doméstica, sin embargo el hecho de no atender a su familia la hizo regresar a su comunidad y dedicarse por completo al cuidado de sus hijos y  su actividad. Desde que era muy pequeña su madre la instruyó en el arte de bordar, aún recuerda con una sonrisa cómo su hermana mayor se burló de ella ya que su primer bordado resultó estar muy desordenado, "ese día mi hermana Teresa dijo que mi bordado se parecía al perro de la casa ya que éste siempre andaba con el pelo enmarañado". Actualmente es una de las mejores artesanas de la región, le solicitan muchas piezas sobre todo  para celebraciones religiosas como bodas, bautizos, comuniones, etc. Por tal motivo en esta ocasión solicita un préstamo a VisionFund para comprar tela, hilos y estambres.
   El negocio ha presentado resultados muy favorables para toda su familia, mantiene una clientela muy solvente y el hecho de dedicarse a lo que la apasiona le resulta invaluable. Por ahora su mayor meta es apoyar a sus hijos para que se desarrollen profesionalmente.
   Los demás integrantes del grupo El Mirador son María Antonia quien invertirá en fajas; Berenice, en una papelería; Teresa, en trajes típicos; Beatriz, en mercería y María de los Ángeles, en bocinas y luces. 
*La fotografía fue tomada en las escaleras del quiosco municipal, Doña Julia es quien viste el suéter color gris*
texts.en:
REVISED
El Mirador group comes from a community that preserves characteristics of the Mazahua culture like clothing, language, music and dance. Their economy revolves around farming, especially of corn, as well as handicrafts. The Mazahua women are known to be the best artisans in the region.

Julia is a hard-working woman from a family with many values that she wants to keep and pass on to her own children. For a while, she worked in Mexico City as a housekeeper, but being away from her family made her return to her community and devote herself entirely to taking care of her children and working on her craft.

From a young age, her mother taught her the art of embroidery. She recalls with a smile when her older sister made fun of how her first embroidery was very messy and resembled the family dog's tangled fur.

She is currently one of the best artisans in the region, and many of her pieces are specifically requested for religious celebrations like weddings, baptisms, communions, etc.

Therefore, she is asking for a loan through VisionFund to buy fabric, thread and yarn. 

The embroidery business has been very good for her whole family, and she has retained a very reliable clientele. To be able to dedicate herself to what she is passionate about is invaluable to her.  Now, her main goal is to support her children so that they can grow in their professional lives.

The other members of El Mirador group are María Antonia, who will invest in sashes; Berenice, in a stationery shop; Teresa, in traditional garments; Beatriz, in a sewing supply shop, and María de los Ángeles, in speakers and lights.

*The photograph was taken on the steps of the town pavilion. Julia is in the gray sweater.*

loans.use: to buy thread, yarn, checkered fabric, etc.

location.town: San Nicolas Guadalupe, San Felipe del Progreso
